Arg.V:
#!/bin/bash
function updatepk() { if [ ! -z $1 ]; then if [ -e /var/run/yum.pid ];then exit 10 fi result=`yum -y update $1 2>&1` status=$? commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: command not found"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: No such file or directory"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "lock /var/run/yum.pid"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "/var/run/yum.pid: another copy is running"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "There was an error communicating with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "This system is not registered with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "No Repositories Available to Set Up"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "Error Class Code: 9 Error Class Info: Invalid System Credentials"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isscriptletfailed=`echo $result | grep -E "error:" | grep -E "scriptlet failed, exit status 255"` if [ "$isscriptletfailed" != "" ]; then exit 6 fi if [ $status -ne 0 ];then exit 7 fi fi } updatepk oprofile
exit 0

if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi

exit 0

Vulnerability.Title: oprofile bug fix and enhancement update
Vulnerability.Description: OProfile is a low-overhead, system-wide profiler that uses the performance monitoring hardware on the processor to retrieve information about the kernel and executables on the system. This update fixes the following bugs: Previously, when profiling performance of Java just-in-time (JIT) compiled code with static huge pages enabled, OProfile's operf command recorded a large number of event samples to anonymous memory (in anon_hugepage) instead of to the appropriate Java method. With this update, operf recognizes the static huge page identifiers and correctly maps samples to Java methods when using statically allocated huge pages. (BZ#1180512) Previously, OProfile did not properly track changes in memory maps. Consequently, when a region of memory was remapped, OProfile did not properly attribute samples for that region and the sample was lost. Users could observe the problem in code running on certain Java Runtime Environments. This bug has been fixed, and the opreport tool now works as expected with the Just-In-Time translated code that has sections of memory remapped. (BZ#1254341) Prior to this update, OProfile generated incorrect XML output. As a consequence, validation of the XML output by the opreport tool failed. A patch has been applied, and the generated XML output now passes validation checks as expected. (BZ#1254341) To properly select an event, some new Intel processors require not only the base event number but also additional bits to be set in the unit mask. Previously, the additional bits in the unit mask remained unset, thus being incorrectly set to zero. As a consequence, performance monitoring hardware was not measuring the desired event, and the operf utility returned zero for the LLC_REFS and LLC_MISSES events on the 2nd, 3rd, and 4th generation Intel Core and Intel Xeon processors. With this update, OProfile code has been fixed to set the unit mask bits as required. As a result, performance events on Intel processors that require non-zero unit masks now work as expected. (BZ#1194246) Previously, when a name of the default unit mask for an event was longer than 11 characters, OProfile truncated the name to 11 characters. Consequently, when the truncated unit mask name was used, OProfile could not find it and returned an error message. With this update, OProfile handles long unit mask names correctly, and the described problem no longer occurs. (BZ#1200806) The operf, ocount, and opjitconv utilities set the POSIXLY_CORRECT environment variable for their internal purposes. Prior to this update, OProfile did not return this environment variable to its previous state, thus potentially affecting profiled tasks. Consequently, profiled tasks that behaved differently when the variable was set, such as rpm rebuilds, did not work as expected. This bug has been fixed, and the OProfile use of POSIXLY_CORRECT now does not affect profiled tasks. (BZ#1185369) A Coverity static analysis test performed on OProfile code revealed potential problems related to argument checks and buffer overflow. The test discovered that a long path name or event unit mask could cause a buffer overflow. This update addresses the warnings produced by the test to prevent such problems. (BZ#1228401) In addition, this update adds the following enhancements: OProfile has been updated to recognize the Intel Xeon Processor D-1500 product family and the processor-specific events for this product family are now available. (BZ#1231397) With this update, OProfile recognizes the 6th Generation Intel Core Processors and it now provides non-architected performance for the 6th Generation Intel Core Processors instead of defaulting to the small subset of architected performance events. (BZ#1238457) Users of oprofile are advised to upgrade to these updated packages, which fix these bugs and add these enhancements. Note for remediation: Please disable the SELinux for RHEL 4/5 when repairing, or some rpm packages will fail to install.
